awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  PIC: Electro-luminescence and doping of black phosphorus for printed lasers on silicon photonic chips
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to demonstrate the viability of a new manufacturing process for on-chip lasers for silicon photonics using printed nanomaterial inks. The difficulty of a scalable method for fabricating on-chip, multi-color lasers is a major challenge for the silicon photonics market. Specifically, today's standard manufacturing of photonic chips does not include on-chip lasers. Without integration of laser engines to drive the circuits, the market potential of light chips is constrained by design and price. The technology developed here can allow foundries to mass produce chips with lasers and open multiple new markets for silicon photonics including wearable photonic sensors, optical data transfer, autonomous vehicle light detection and ranging, quantum information, fiber-optic gyroscopes, and healthcare applications such as immunoassay tests and medical imaging.

This Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project develops on-chip embedded lasers to enable fully functional silicon photonic chip manufacturing. Currently, the laser solutions being employed in silicon photonics include bonded lasers and heterogeneous integration. The system integrators that assemble silicon photonics modules rely on often cumbersome methods of gluing individual lasers to silicon chips, keeping costs high and throughput well below desired levels. The photonic inks developed here will overcome this challenge by enabling an in-foundry laser solution via wafer-scale additive manufacturing. The photonic ink emits broad-spectrum light covering the visible to the near-infrared range and can be tailored to emit at specific wavelength bands relevant to different markets by altering the number of atomic layers. The goals of this Phase I project are to demonstrate electroluminescence from a p-n junction made from doped, few-layer nanomaterials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Disclaimer

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

Broader Impacts:

Optical technologies and electronics are each $500B markets. There is currently a large effort to create a new market at the intersection of these two markets called photonic integrated circuits (PICs). PICs leverage capabilities from both wafer-scale manufacturing of electronics and the unique applications of light-based technologies. Silicon photonics is one sub-class of PIC technology based on mature CMOS semiconductor manufacturing used to make the electronics we use widely in smartphones, computers, and beyond. Silicon photonics is currently deployed in data centers to transmit data within and between racks via optical transceivers which transmit and receive high-bandwidth encoded data signals. This is similar to how optical fibers transmit data over large distances for internet traffic and provides the same benefits of lower power consumption and lower cost. Each data center uses over 100,000 optical transceivers, and the need for cloud infrastructure is growing at a rate of 30% per year. Beyond this initial market, silicon photonics is expected to play a growing role across many sectors including medical devices, autonomous vehicle LIDAR, optical gas sensors, and fiber-optic gyroscopes. The dense integration of photonic components into a single photonic chip will increase the availability of the applications of light to regular people with increased reliability and reduced cost by leveraging high-volume chip manufacturing.

 

The major unmet need for silicon photonics is figuring out how to integrate the laser onto the silicon photonics chip. Currently, individual lasers are being physically adhered onto each chip, but this is costly. Today, the cost of lasers is significant fraction of building a product and will worsen as applications start to require multiple lasers on each chip. Iris Light’s innovation target is to demonstrate and commercialize the first lasers made from printing a light-emitting ink directly onto electronic chips through additive manufacturing techniques such as aerosol jet printing.  The vision for the nanomaterial ink is to be able to create multiple laser devices in a single chip, to open new applications for silicon photonics. For example, in data communications, the largest market for silicon photonics today, one laser powers 100 Gb/s of bandwidth. Iris Light’s technology has the potential to drive additional gains in bandwidth by adding laser density. For example, ten Iris Light on-chip lasers on a single chip would push data rates into the Tb/s regime (1000 Gb/s), which will be required in the next five years by industry. For chemical and medical sensors, low-cost access to tens of molecular markers is enabled by having multiple, affordable light sources on a single chip compared to multiple packaged elements today.

What were the major goals of the project?

The goals of this project were (1) to develop and characterize the nanomaterials needed for our light-emitting ink and (2) to produce printed devices such as photodiodes using our ink to validate the inks are suitable for high-performance opto-electronics.

What was accomplished under these goals? 

During Phase I of this NSF STTR project, we focused on de-risking the light-emitting ink and the ability to print devices using the ink. First, we developed and characterized our nanomaterial ink. We showed that the ink has very high electrical conductivity and we characterized its light-emitting properties. Next, we developed our ability to print the ink onto predesignated areas to produce semiconductor devices, such as photodiodes. We characterized these devices and showed that they perform well. It should be noted that the semiconducting inks that we developed can be used in a broader field than only silicon photonics. They can be printed onto flexible materials as well as substrates that are not silicon. As part of this project, we printed onto flexible glass materials and plastic to demonstrate feasibility.

Intellectual Merit:

This project is pushing the boundaries of scientific knowledge in key areas, such as semiconducting inks, 2-dimensional nanomaterials, printed electronics, and optoelectronics. The most fascinating to us is the intersection of these areas. For example, instead of observing how individual nanoflakes can be used to make an optoelectronic device, we are investigating how an ensemble of thousands of printed nanoflakes can be used to make devices. This knowledge is not only interesting, but far more technologically relevant.

What opportunities for training and professional development has the project provided?

The project provided professional development for scientific staff to gain valuable experience with sought after skills such as aerosol-jet printing, semiconductor device fabrication, and silicon photonics.

 


Last Modified: 05/12/2023
Modified by: Chad Husko
